Award.AwardTitle: LTREB: Evolutionary Dynamics in a Rapidly Changing Environment
Award.AbstractNarration:
The purpose of this study is to understand how natural selection on various physiological, behavioral, and life history traits in a model organism, yellow-bellied marmots, varies over time in a rapidly changing environment. By following the fate of individually-marked marmots, this research will provide new insights on the limits of evolutionary responses to environmental change. This research will transform our views of potentially "good" and "bad" changes that are driven by the environment. These methods and results should be applicable to a variety of other species that are likely to initially do "better" but may ultimately do "worse" from earlier arrival of spring conditions.

The broader impacts of this project will include: (1) recruitment and training of graduate and undergraduate students from under-represented groups; (2) wide dissemination of research results to scientific audiences and the general public via scientific and popular articles and talks, and engagement with science journalists; (3) maintenance of Marmot Minutes (a blog), The Marmot Burrow (a website), and The Marmots of RMBL (a website); and (4) continuation of one of the world's longest-running studies that follows the fate of individually-marked mammals. This dataset has become an important window on the effects of climate change on a hibernating vertebrate, and a valuable data set that can be used to explore both population and evolutionary dynamics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF LTREB provided vital financial support to sustain a long-term study of individually-marked yellow-bellied marmots that began in 1962.

 

The intellectual merits of this project included: (1) understanding how selection changes over time, thus providing insights to better understand the limits of evolutionary responses to environmental change; (2) comprehensively studying this phenomenon by studying how changes in reproductive success and survival affects a variety of traits, and how changes in these traits will affect reproduction and survival; (3) integrating proximate and ultimate mechanisms using novel tools to study causal inference.

 

We have achieved these merits. During the period of support, the marmot project produced over 45 papers and one book on the behavior, ecology, and evolution of yellow-bellied marmots; many more are in review, preparation, and others have been facilitated by the support provided from this grant. We have gained new insights into how ‘plastic’ marmots’ responses are to environmental changes. We expected that increases in selection pressure with time were to be observed in the first five years at the low elevation site given that we already have observed changes in body mass there in the last few years. We did not find this; rather we found that phenotypic plasticity is present and seemingly provides sufficient adaptive variation to permit the marmots to respond to environmental fluctuations. However, because of the lag between low and high elevation sites, we still expect some de-coupling of dynamics at these sites. We developed new hormonal assays, and are in the process of developing new genomic tools. These tools permit novel integrative questions to be asked in free-living mammals that are becoming a model system for both studies of social behavior and climate change.

 

The broader impacts of this project included: (1) recruitment and training of graduate and undergraduate students from under-represented groups; (2) wide dissemination of research results to scientific audiences and general public via scientific and popular articles and talks, and working with science journalists; (3) maintenance of Marmot Minutes (a blog), The Marmot Burrow (a website), and The Marmots of RMBL (a website); and (4) ‘keeping alive’ of one of the world’s longest-running studies following the fate of individually-marked mammals.

 

We have achieved these broader impacts. We have trained many students and postdoctoral fellows (including women and those from under-represented ethnic groups) both from UCLA and other institutions. Trained personnel have gone on to graduate study in STEM disciplines or medical school, have completed their dissertations, and have acquired postdoctoral fellowships and faculty jobs. The marmot work has received substantial press coverage and the freely available dataset has become a valuable data set to explore both population and evolutionary dynamics in a wild mammal population.
